--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Jeff Clune  wrote:
> =
This discussion raises the larger question of whether you could have truly =
temporal problems that did not require spatially distinct processing stream=
s

Maybe I misunderstand here something, but a truly temporal problem would=
 be any kind of sequence learning (e.g. navigation, episodic memories, moto=
r skills)?! Learning of information that have a temporal order, comparing s=
equences, recognizing sequences. The area that has been associated with the=
se kinds of tasks is the hippocampus with its areas dental gyrus, ca3 and c=
a1. Information are processed along those three areas but each area returns=
 also feedback to the entorhinal cortex (which in turn connects to the cort=
ex). The hippocampus has been implicated in many different functions (depen=
ding on the species in which it is observed) but maybe common to all proble=
m domains of the species that have a hippocampus is the fact that it has so=
mething to do with sequence learning. 

Given the fact that the anatomy of =
the hippocampus is very well conserved across evolution it seems to me that=
 the hippocampus is an excellent example, that spatial properties of biolog=
ical neural networks can also be exploited to solve temporal problems. Its =
modular structure seems to play crucial role here.

For more see: http://ww=
w.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/16881079

> As such, even if our technique did no=
t encourage modularity for simple problems where no separate processing str=
eams are required, it probably is still important for most (all?) complex p=
roblems.  

In this context I was wondering whether it could be helpful to =
measure the ratio between the current number of edges in a network and the =
number of edges that have to be removed in order to have a modular network.=
 Maybe, this ratio could help to provide an analytical solution for the que=
stion how likely it is that modularity emerges in larger networks.
